R: @dhalperi

Installing tox is enough. virtualenv is a required package for tox and they will be installed together.

Travis does not have tox or virutalenv installed on the machine. We install them in the --user mode also. They will not be on the user PATH, so it is important to call them with their absolute paths. That should be: `$HOME/.local/bin/tox` for Jenkins. However note that this is platform dependent and for example on osx it will be `$HOME/Library/Python/2.7/bin/tox`. 

The install path could be customized by setting the `PYTHONUSERBASE` environment variable. I have tried this only on linux and I am not sure how it will behave on other systems.

```
export PYTHONUSERBASE=/somedirectory
pip install --user tox
/somedirectory/bin/tox ...
```

Cleanup of this is also easier. If we can manage to install things in a directory of our own choice we can just rm it at the cleanup phase.

`mvn  -pl sdks/java/io/google-cloud-platform -DskipITs=false -DintegrationTestPipelineOptions='[ "--project=apache-beam-testing", "--tempRoot=gs://neville-steel-us/beam", "--runner=org.apache.beam.runners.dataflow.testing.TestDataflowRunner" ]' install`


You need to have a Bigtable instance you can run against... an unfortunate limitation, but it makes sense if you are going to develop tests. The write test is the one that is broken, so you should just run that one. It sets up its own state, so should be nice and self-contained for running.

Resuming review.

I just pushed basic support for Read.Bound which basically seems to support IOs without specific implementations (except for HadoopIO which is a runner-specific transformation).
For Bounded pipelines, I would say that this is still missing higher-level, optimized, translations for IOs that should be added by 1-to-1 mapping of BoundedSource to DataFrameReader (where possible) or InputFormat (for example SequenceFiles).

If anyone sees a better low-level entry-point to creating RDDs/DataFrames(sets) from Sources please let me know.

I suspect that the travis-CI tests are failing because they are using the wrong path for the expected output. (Using `withoutSharding` changes the `shardNameTemplate`).

BTW, would you be more comfortable with passing "1" shard in the example as an option ?
For example: --numShards=1
So the user explicitly declares this, and we're not setting `withoutSharding` for him.

@charlesccychen Pylint released a new version (1.6.1) to PyPi recently. It adds a new warning for extra new lines at the end of the files. It is warning about a total of 3 places including this one. I will fix them. This one you can remove the extra line at the end of the dependecy.py file. (FYI: https://pylint.readthedocs.io/en/latest/whatsnew/changelog.html#what-s-new-in-pylint-1-6-1)

Jenkins seems to be consistently failing on the RAT check
Looks like this was broken by #537. I've wiped out the workspace and we'll see if that helps.

**Tests using `PCollectionViewAssert`**: Filtering them out is the right thing to do. The way you have it is fine to get unblocked. It would be even better to tag specific test methods with `@Category(StaticSideInputs.class)` (from the [capability matrix doc](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1fICxq32t9yWn9qXhmT07xpclHeHX2VlUyVtpi2WzzGM/edit?usp=sharing) shared by @tgroh) and then use `<excludedGroups>` in your pom. This way you aren't eliminating the whole test class, just the method.

**Test timeouts**: It may be infeasible to run all these `RunnableOnService` tests in the presubmit and in Travis. For Dataflow, we run just a couple in the presubmit and then the rest as a [post-submit Jenkins job](https://builds.apache.org/job/beam_PostCommit_RunnableOnService_GoogleCloudDataflow). It probably makes sense to do this for many runners, so that is also no problem. Do you know whether it is just overheads or whether there is a real performance problem?

For right now, there's a [RAT plugin failure](https://builds.apache.org/job/beam_PreCommit_MavenVerify/2177/org.apache.beam$beam-parent/console) in the `runners-parent` module. If we fix that, then then Jenkins should be willing to run your tests to completion even if it takes a long time.

From there, since traffic on the branch will be low enough, I think we can probably check it in to a feature branch and then set up the postsubmit job and try to see if we can speed up the tests.

It looks like the RAT plugin was seeing files that needed to be cleaned up from another branch. We've just adjusted the Jenkins configuration so those files should be cleaned. Go ahead and force a rebuild via rebase and force push, or dummy commit, and we should see Jenkins succeed or timeout.

Jenkins broke on checkstyle.

FWIW, I think removing all side inputs as you've done is actually cleaner, as whether a side input is deferred or known at runtime should not be detectable by the callee (and allows the caller more freedom). If something is needed by start/finish, it can be placed in the constructor.
Bad merge! Let me clean this up.
